Award.AwardTitle: Preparing STEM Leaders at Rutgers University

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Increasing persistence and retention in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) is essential for building a highly qualified STEM workforce. This project at Rutgers University will support the development of a rigorous and structured peer leader training program in STEM disciplines: Preparation in STEM Leadership (PSL) Program. The PSL Program will serve as a model for academic support services that moves beyond remedial support to create an environment of scholarship and enrichment. Such a transformation will provide a national model for maximizing the potential of academic support services using similar active, collaborative, and student-centered methods. The complementary development of content knowledge, pedagogical knowledge, and leadership and communication skills at the college level will contribute to a better equipped STEM workforce because these participants will be prepared for leadership positions that involve mentoring, teaching, and training others. In addition, this project will enable the compilation of a set of complementary valid and reliable assessment instruments to measure the cognitive and professional development of peer leaders. The evaluation of the PSL Program will identify specific criteria essential for successful peer leader training, which will serve as standards for programs within and beyond Rutgers. The PSL Program will combine extended training in STEM content, mentoring, communication, leadership, and group facilitation with a 3-credit, 300-level pedagogy course to create a comprehensive professional development program. The PSL Program will be evaluated using a combination of quantitative and qualitative data to measure learning gains in participants' content knowledge and pedagogical content knowledge, changes in student?s attitudes and epistemological beliefs related to learning science, improvement in job performance, and the development of leadership and communication skills.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Specific Aim 1: To develop a rigorous and structured Peer Leader Training Program in STEM disciplines that will expand upon and solidify the infrastructure for the Learning Centers’ existing Training Program and Learning Assistant (LA) Program’s pedagogy course: Peer Instruction Education.

Outcome #1.1: Providing training and professional development to undergraduate academic Peer Leaders (PLs) in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines. From 2015 - 2018, 51 academic Peer Leaders (including tutors, learning assistants (LAs), study group leaders, undergraduate teaching assistants, and teaching interns) participated in the Preparation in STEM Leadership (PSL) Program, which required co-enrollment in a pedagogy course and participation in four 80-minute training and professional development workshops each semester. The 300-level, 3-credit pedagogy course was initially created only to support LAs. Workshop, on the other hand, were open to any academic PL on campus, and the topics of the workshops related to leadership, communication, learning theory, and access and equity.The PSL Program provided 18 additional PLs with the opportunity to enroll in this course and demonstrated that PLs who are not in the LA program were interested in taking the course. Starting in the 2016-2017 academic year, the Learning Centers (LCs) began offering the pedagogy course in the spring semester and opened enrollment to any student in an academic PL position. Additionally, the course has been expanded to include the 18 PLs in a new program that offers a seminar course for first-year international students.

Outcome #1.2: Creation of Learning Center (LC) Position: Developmental Specialist for Training Programs. To support the expanding need for academic PL training and professional development across the Rutgers’ New Brunswick campus, the LCs created a new position that oversees the coordination, registration, and tracking of workshops, develops in-person and online modules, and directs the assessment of PLs who attend these workshops. During the 3 years of the PSL Program, 1,579 PLs participated in at least one workshop offered at the LCs.

Outcome #1.3: Enhancement of PL training efforts across campus. With a focus on research-based practices and assessment of PL development, we have been able to revise training methods and increase the number of PLs on campus who are served by our training program. We now serve all PLs teaching the RU-First-Year International Student Transition course, which enrolls the majority of first-semester international students across campus. Additionally, both the Computer Science Peer Mentor and the Math Peer Mentor Programs have transitioned out of individual departments and into the centralized LA Program, primarily due to the successful outcomes of the LA Program and the consistency of the LC training model. Feedback we received through the assessments used for the PSL Program also led to improvements in our training practices to include an intensive hybrid (in-person and online) training program and additional workshop topics.

Specific Aim 2: To compile a set of complementary assessment instruments that can be used to assess the extent of PLs’ development in content knowledge, pedagogical knowledge, leadership practices, and communication skills, without resulting in assessment fatigue among participants.

Outcome #2.1: Assessment of academic PLs: During the three years of the PSL Program, we collected assessment data from 380 PLs who consented to participate in our research study. Lessons learned from these assessment efforts, and from analyzing data, have informed the integration of assessment practices into the PL training workshops, pedagogy courses, and pre-employment orientation requirements. By devoting time to assessment activities within these sessions, we demonstrate to the PLs that we value the assessments, and we have higher response rates. At a large institution like Rutgers, holistically assessing hundreds of PLs each year across multiple areas of development requires significant time and human resources to collect, clean, transcribe, and analyze data. We have increased the use of online methods for data collection to reduce cleaning and transcription costs. Finally, assessing PLs across multiple STEM disciplines requires additional content expertise. As a consequence, the LCs have drawn upon their existing relationships with faculty across campus and invited these colleagues to participate in the analysis process. Participating in the assessment efforts and discussing findings have enhanced these relationships and strengthened the Rutgers network of faculty and staff who are interested in PLs’ development and the evaluation of programs that incorporate or utilize PL positions.

 

Outcome #2.2: Broader Impacts. At Rutgers, the PSL Program, and the associated research study, have influenced the assessment of PLs and the design and evaluation of new PL programs, such as First-Year International Transfer Seminar course. Outside of Rutgers, the PSL Program has reached a broader audience through presentations at national and regional meetings of the College Reading and Learning Association, the National College Learning Center Association, the American Chemical Society, and the International Learning Assistant Alliance.
